15/ The Afghans that had helped U.S. efforts in Afghanistan were finally, in early 2022, being vetted to come in with Temporary Protected Status. But that‚Äôs the next and final chapter - coming to the United States. More on that soon.

14/ In December 2021, I met with senior White House officials who - along with @SecMayorkas, Deputy Secretary Tien and State Department staff - agreed to arrange for thorough security & health vetting of the Afghans in Albania & some in other third countries as well.

13/ Upon our return, Sen. Ernst & I collaborated on a bipartisan, bicameral letter to the administration, urging that Afghans who had helped the U.S. and happened to get to a third country be vetted and treated the same as the other Afghans who got on a military plane.
12/ As I left Albania, I told them that I‚Äôd do everything I could to get them to the U.S., and then there‚Äôd be no limits on what they and their children could achieve.

11/ What I told them was this: I could not & would not forget them, because I saw in each of them the faces of my grandparents & great-grandparents who also left their home countries for safety, security & a better chance at life. And now, their grandchild is a congresswoman.

10/ They asked me ‚Äî begged me ‚Äî not to forget them. I remember the lump in my throat as grown men and women begged for their children‚Äôs lives and the opportunity to continue contributing in the United States. Anywho who has been or has met a refugee knows that desperation.
9/ They were raw with emotion, tears, and a desperation for their children‚Äôs future. Our translator even had to swap out because he, too, couldn‚Äôt contain his emotions.

8/ They were exhausted from having to flee their home country and desperately worried about family they left behind, but they also felt a deep uncertainly about what would happen to them. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fbk1VS8aIAAgehH.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fbk1WQeaUAc33ER.jpg

7/ After @SenJoniErnst and I had lunch and hosted a roundtable with the Afghans, I held a private meeting with the 114 who I felt personally responsible for. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fbk1QTpVQAcEHLT.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fbk1R5yUcAMHGyV.jpg
6/ They, along with some additional Afghans, were living in a moderate seaside resort on the Adriatic. It‚Äôs no exaggeration to say that this was one of the most moving experiences of my career.

5/ In November 2021, I organized a bipartisan congressional delegation with some of my colleagues to visit Albania, thank the officials I‚Äôd been working with, and to finally meet the Afghan families for myself. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fbk1JdnUYAEtjok.jpg

4/ We organized Zoom calls with the families to keep in touch & give them any updates I had about State Department processing, though everyone knew that they were overwhelmed with 80,000 Afghans who had just come out at the same time.

3/ They were not going to settle in Albania permanently, and had to work their way through a lengthy and uncertain process for the U.S. They lived in fear of being sent back to Afghanistan. https://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/politics/2021/11/30/afghans-msu-ties-limbo-albania-fearful-being-forgotten/8768781002/

2/ @SpiritAmerica, an incredible organization, cared for their needs and were wonderful partners for my office in this chapter. But while the Afghans were safe, this chapter was, in many ways, the hardest part of the story, because of the incredible limbo they lived with.

Part 2 of 3: A few days ago, I posted about the desperate 10 days it took to get 114 Afghans, most of them affiliated with @MichiganStateU, out of Kabul a year ago. We got them to the safety of Albania, a country that was extraordinarily generous to offer them safe harbor. 1/
